articles.headline: At Last, Recovery Heads Where the Fed Wants It
articles.snippet: Several notable indicators of economic health, including the Consumer Price Index, finally seem to be moving in the direction the Federal Reserve says is needed for a strong recovery.
articles.abstract: Several notable indicators of economic health, including the Consumer Price Index, finally seem to be moving in the direction the Federal Reserve says is needed for a strong recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve finally seems to be getting what it wants.

articles.headline: Fire Season Starts Early, and Fiercely
articles.snippet: Officials in California have already battled 1,400 wildfires this year, twice the number they would respond to in the same period in a normal year.
articles.abstract: Officials in California have already battled 1,400 wildfires this year, twice the number they would respond to in the same period in a normal year.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The fire season here in the hot, dry West now lasts roughly 75 days longer than it did a decade ago, and nearly three dozen fires have been burning up and down California in the last two days, weeks before a normal season begins.

articles.headline: As Barbara Walters Retires, the Big TV Interview Signs Off, Too
articles.snippet: Ms. Walters has been the queen of the TV celebrity “get.” But stars and politicians no longer need the networks to reach their public.
articles.abstract: Ms. Walters has been the queen of the TV celebrity “get.” But stars and politicians no longer need the networks to reach their public.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a Wednesday night in early March 1999, Barbara Walters invited a small group of friends and colleagues to her Manhattan apartment to watch her two-hour interview with Monica Lewinsky. During a commercial break, Ms. Walters stood by the window, looking out over Central Park, and noticed something peculiar. “There’s no traffic on Fifth Avenue,” she observed.

articles.headline: Workers Seize City in Eastern Ukraine From Separatists
articles.snippet: Pro-Russian militants melted away as steelworkers and miners, armed only with protective clothing and hard hats, began patrols in the city of Mariupol.
articles.abstract: Pro-Russian militants melted away as steelworkers and miners, armed only with protective clothing and hard hats, began patrols in the city of Mariupol.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARIUPOL, Ukraine — Thousands of steelworkers fanned out on Thursday through the city of Mariupol, establishing control over the streets and banishing the pro-Kremlin militants who until recently had seemed to be consolidating their grip on power, dealing a setback to Russia and possibly reversing the momentum in eastern Ukraine.

articles.headline: Convicted of Felonies, Banks Are Allowed to Stay in Business
articles.snippet: The Justice Department has gone to great lengths to guarantee that convicted banks will not be treated as criminals.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department has gone to great lengths to guarantee that convicted banks will not be treated as criminals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two large international banks — Credit Suisse and BNP Paribas — are expected to plead guilty to criminal charges within the next few weeks. If that happens, they will pay large fines and officially be felons.

articles.headline: U.S. Officials Question Ability of Nigeria to Rescue Hostages
articles.snippet: Testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, administration officials offered an unusually candid and public assessment of the Nigerian military.
articles.abstract: Testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, administration officials offered an unusually candid and public assessment of the Nigerian military.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Obama administration officials on Thursday questioned whether the Nigerian military is able to rescue, even with international help, more than 260 schoolgirls abducted last month, giving impetus to a social media campaign calling for the United States to do more to free the hostages.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Brian Knowlton

articles.headline: Full Recovery Still Years Away for Many in Euro Zone
articles.snippet: The uneven nature of the recovery — between a group of strong countries in the north and a larger swath of weak nations in the southern rim — has made it difficult for the overall economy to gain momentum.
articles.abstract: The uneven nature of the recovery — between a group of strong countries in the north and a larger swath of weak nations in the southern rim — has made it difficult for the overall economy to gain momentum.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Despite recent optimism that Europe’s economy is finally turning a corner, a stark reality remains: The situation is still fragile.

articles.headline: Times Seeks to Reassure Its Staff After Abramson’s Ouster
articles.snippet: Senior editors met with employees to reiterate that Jill Abramson’s departure did not reflect sexism and was not about pay disparity, but about a style of leadership.
articles.abstract: Senior editors met with employees to reiterate that Jill Abramson’s departure did not reflect sexism and was not about pay disparity, but about a style of leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after The New York Times Company announced that it had dismissed Jill Abramson, The Times’s first female executive editor, it found itself mired in controversy, having to reassure employees and rebut reports that her removal was related to her complaints about receiving less pay than her male predecessors.
articles.byline: By Leslie Kaufman and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: Narendra Modi’s Ambitious Agenda Will Face Difficult Obstacles
articles.snippet: The Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party’s enormous victory clearly reflects a rapid change in Indian society as urbanization and economic growth break down old voting patterns.
articles.abstract: The Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party’s enormous victory clearly reflects a rapid change in Indian society as urbanization and economic growth break down old voting patterns.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Addressing a euphoric crowd Friday afternoon, Narendra Modi rallied the public to join him in taking on challenges of a vast scale. He has floated the idea of building “a hundred new cities,” of extending a high-speed rail network across the subcontinent and undertaking the herculean task of cleaning the Ganges River.

articles.headline: For Democrats, Texas Push Gets an Early Shove
articles.snippet: Battleground Texas’s goal was to make the state competitive, but when State Senator Wendy Davis, a Democrat, announced her candidacy, their fates became intertwined.
articles.abstract: Battleground Texas’s goal was to make the state competitive, but when State Senator Wendy Davis, a Democrat, announced her candidacy, their fates became intertwined.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — The instructions seemed simple enough: Knock on your neighbors’ doors and tell them to vote for Wendy Davis in Texas’ election for governor.

articles.headline: G.M. Is Fined Over Safety and Called a Lawbreaker
articles.snippet: In a civil settlement in which General Motors will pay a $35 million penalty, federal regulators said the automaker also agreed to change its internal review process after a defect was linked to 13 deaths and a recall.
articles.abstract: In a civil settlement in which General Motors will pay a $35 million penalty, federal regulators said the automaker also agreed to change its internal review process after a defect was linked to 13 deaths and a recall.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Saying that safety practices at General Motors were “broken,” federal regulators on Friday imposed the biggest punishment they could on the automaker and condemned it over its failure to promptly report a defect that G.M. has linked to 13 deaths.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Danielle Ivory
